awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Nanoindenter for Materials Science and Biomaterials Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the acquisition of a nanoindenter for fundamental investigations of advanced engineering materials and biomaterials.  The mechanical properties of materials are intricately linked to how they function. Understanding how these properties influence material behavior is critical for both the design of advanced engineered materials and the response of biological tissues to disease.  This instrument will enable quantitative mechanical characterization of materials impacting several scientific disciplines and provide foundational understanding of engineering, construction, and biological materials.  Additionally, targeted K-12 educational outreach activities will allow students and teachers to participate in hands-on experiments and explore STEM careers. These opportunities will impacting low socioeconomic status communities in the Arkansas Delta.  

This nanoindenter acquisition will provide a comprehensive nanomechanics platform for quantitatively measuring elastic modulus, hardness, deformation/wear, fatigue strength, and friction of materials.   The unique capabilities of the tool will impact the following research projects: 1) Investigating strengthening mechanisms and the role dislocation dynamics in novel high-strength core-shell nanostructures; 2) Assessing the hardness of caries-affected teeth to understand how the pathogen Streptococcus mutans causes tooth decay; 3) in vitro mechanical characterization of cardiovascular tissues at physiological conditions; 4) Understanding the nanomechanistic properties of polymeric asphalt binders with high-resolution spatial mapping of elastic modulus, hardness, and complex shear modulus; 5) Precision nanomanufacturing research to improve the uniformity metallic nanopatterned surfaces produced by thin film dewetting and pulsed electric wave generation; and 6) interfacial strain measurements of III-V semiconductor quantum dot wells grown on sapphire.  Together, these projects represent multi-disciplinary research collaborations across engineering and biological sciences. 

This project is jointly funded by the division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation (CMMI), the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), and the Major Instrumentation Research Program (MRI).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the acquisition of an instrumented nanoindentation tool to enhance research efforts in materials engineering, manufacturing, and biomaterials at Arkansas State University.  The tool is capable of non-destructive measurement of elastic modulus and hardness of traditional engineering materials, as well as dynamic mechanical analysis, nanoscratch testing, and scanning wear.  Specialized modifications include an extended-range transducer for characterizing low-stiffness biomaterials, an integrated heating stage, and a unique, first-of-its-kind heated fluid cell with a controllable gas atmosphere for performing measurements on biological tissues at physiological conditions.  As a result, the nanoindenter is a comprehensive experimental nanomechanics platform which has been configured for quantative investifation of all classes of materials, from metals to biological tissues.

To date, the tool has been utilized to investigate a wide range of material systems, including: NiCr alloys for solid lubrication applictions in space; molybdenum disulfide coatings with hexagonal carbide inclusions to investigate wear rate improvements; pull-off adhesion characterization of functionalized silica nanoparticle coatings for self-cleaning applications in solar photovoltaic power generation; and mechanical stiffness characterization of mouse heart tissue to better understand cardiac disease.  Other applications of interest include understanding the mechanical behavior of enzymatically-degraded low density polyethylene, the mechanics of dental tissues affected by tooth decay, advanced paving materials, and precision nanomanufactuing applications.  The tool has also been used to enhance classes and teaching laboratories, primarily at the graduate level, giving students hands-on exposure to advanced mechanical property measurements of both traditional engineering materials and biological materials.

Research activities enabled by this instrument address critical biomedical issues affecting the US, including heart diseases, which is the No. 1 cause of death in the US, and dental health related to tooth decay, which has a yearly estimated economic impact exceeding $30 billion in the US.  Additional impacts on STEM outreach and research participation for under-represented populations in the rural Arkansas Delta include research support and professional development opportunities to increase the pool of under-represented STEM graduates at all academic levels in Arkansas’ workforce.


Last Modified: 12/24/2024
Modified by: Robert Fleming

Specialized modifications include an extended-range transducer for characterizing low-stiffness biomaterials, an integrated heating stage, and a unique, first-of-its-kind heated fluid cell with a controllable gas atmosphere for performing measurements on biological tissues at physiological conditions. As a result, the nanoindenter is a comprehensive experimental nanomechanics platform which has been configured for quantative investifation of all classes of materials, from metals to biological tissues.

Other applications of interest include understanding the mechanical behavior of enzymatically-degraded low density polyethylene, the mechanics of dental tissues affected by tooth decay, advanced paving materials, and precision nanomanufactuing applications. Research activities enabled by this instrument address critical biomedical issues affecting the US, including heart diseases, which is the No. 1 cause of death in the US, and dental health related to tooth decay, which has a yearly estimated economic impact exceeding $30 billion in the US. Additional impacts on STEM outreach and research participation for under-represented populations in the rural Arkansas Delta includeresearch support and professional development opportunities to increase the pool of under-represented STEM graduates at all academic levels in Arkansas workforce.
